body.raw: Hello world! This is my first post.

body.raw:
As I ponder what to write for this blog, I can't help but marvel at the incredible skill of other bloggers. 
Starting this blog feels a bit overwhelming, unsure of where to begin or how to express my thoughts. 
I'm optimistic that with time, this process will become more natural.
Additionally, I'm grappling with the challenge of making code snippets visually appear like code in my blogs.

document.title: Light and Dark mode
document.description: How to toggle light and dark mode

body.raw:
I love the idea of a dark and light theme on a website. After discovering this feature on the Next.js website, I decided to experiment with it myself. To begin, I downloaded the 'next-themes' package. ```jsx $ npm install next-themes # or $ yarn add next-themes ``` Then, I made a new file in the component ```jsx import { useTheme } from "next-themes" export function LDMode() { const { setTheme, theme } = useTheme() ``` I name it LDMode(where L stands for light and D for dark). This component serves as the button allowing users to toggle between light and dark themes. I implemented the useTheme hook to so that the theme variable will represent the active theme at any time. Then I incorporated this variable into a button like so: ```jsx return ( ) } ``` I got the icons from https://heroicons.com/. Then I copied and pasted the SVG code into LDMode.tsx in components folder: ```jsx //this is the dark //this is the light ``` Then I made a theme component as follows: ```jsx "use client" import * as React from "react" import { ThemeProvider as NextThemesProvider } from "next-themes" import type { ThemeProviderProps } from "next-themes/dist/types" export function ThemeProvider({ children, ...props }: ThemeProviderProps) { return {children} } ``` This code establishes a custom 'ThemeProvider' component, serving as a wrapper around the 'ThemeProvider' provided by the 'next-themes' library. It is intended for use in the application's root to seamlessly manage themes across the entire component tree. Finally, I added the these components to my main layout.tsx page. ```jsx //components import Navbar from './components/nav' import { LDMode } from './components/ldmode'; import { ThemeProvider } from './components/theme'; const inter = Inter({ subsets: ['latin'] }) export const metadata: Metadata = { title: 'Create Next App', description: 'Generated by create next app', } export default function RootLayout({ children, }: { children: React.ReactNode; }) { const classNames = [GeistSans.variable, GeistMono.variable].join(' '); return ( {/* // */}
{children}
); } ``` This is how I got light and dark mode to work on my landing page!
